p: To date, there are many methods for the preparation of 2-aminothiazole and their derivatives such as Hantzsch, Cook Heilborn, and Tchernic have been reported [ 25]. The first and most frequently used method is Hantzsch’s synthesis [ 26], who originated it in 1887, involving the reaction of α-halo carbonyl compounds with thioureas or thioamides in the presence of bromine/iodine, silica chloride, 1,3-di-nbutylimidazolium tetrafluoroborate, ammonium 12-molybdophosphate, and cyclodextrin, aq. NaICl 2 or using various homogenous and heterogonous catalysts (Fig. 2) [ 27– 29]. Another method of 6 preparations involves condensation rhodanamine (H 2N–SCN) with the tenfold excess of ethyl acetoacetate in a melt at 100–120 °C [ 30]. Condensation of ethyl acetoacetate with formamidine disulfide hydrobromide was performed analogously, providing 6 in 57–62% yield [ 31]. Carbonyl compounds and thiourea can be combined directly into the thiazole ring using bromine as the condensing agent [ 32]. Reaction of ethyl β-ethoxyacrylate with N-bromosuccinimide (NBS) produces a novel intermediate, α-bromo-α-formylacetate hemiacetal. Cyclization of the in situ formed hemiacetal with thioureas, also afforded 2-aminothiazole-5-carboxylates [ 33]. Moreover, reaction of the trichloroether with diethylene glycol gives the cyclic acetal, which may also be converted to 2-aminothiazole (Fig. 3) [ 34].
